results.content: I wish all courses could be as great as this one. Trevoir takes his time and explains what he is doing and WHY he is doing it. He makes a few mistakes here and there but didn't edit them out of the course. He backtracks and fixes them which is really useful to see as we all make silly errors. I was struggling with .NET Core until i started this course , now i am getting a much better understanding of it. I even understand DI !! Thank you Trevoir, you've made a real difference.

response.content: This is great to hear Paul. I'm glad you found value in the mistakes made, whether they were intentional or not. I look forward to seeing the great things you will build after this.

results.content:
First, I don't know why people are complaining about Trevoir copying or skipping over some things. The only stuff he copies is from the project content he did or generated with us and that is exactly what a smart programmer should do! His "skipping" is only after he's gone through everything in detail and then didn't want to waste my time redundantly repeating the exact same stuff. This is already 20 hours long, there are zero valid reasons for those complaints!

Now, I have been using C# for 6 years in a non professional capacity and HTML for 2 years; plus I am fairly well studied. With that said, this course was often intolerable FOR ME. I am an advanced user that looks at everything wearing a "best practice" police lens. Trevoir, mostly (eventually) fixed all the stuff that was constantly irritating me, but I can't tell for sure because it often took a really long time to get there. 

With that said, he is clear, easy to follow and seemingly did what he set out to do, but this course is not geared for someone at my level. I only recommend this course for intermediates. IMO you NEED a fair C# foundation and a bit less HTML context coming in, but if you have to much, then this could be very hard to stomach.

response.content: Thanks for the feedback Joshua.
response.content_html: Thanks for the feedback Joshua.

results.content:
This course was excellent and the lecturer is fantastic at answering question very quickly. My only real complaint would be that you need to take this course with a good background of programming concepts as I find he does very little explaining of concepts. Rather he codes along with you saying what he is doing. (For myself, I have been programming for many years and just needed to learn .net so it worked well for me.) Just as an example, at one point he changes all functions to be async but rather than explaining what asynchronous requests actually are, he simply says that they have a peformance advantage (which is true but doesn't actually explain the concept of them).
Additionally- and this plays into the prior experience factor- there are certain practices that the lecturer uses that are not best coding practices and a new programmer would not be aware of these. Eg. Rewriting code in multiple functions rather than using reusable code

response.content: Thank you for your honest and full review Sara. I will definitely take these points and apply them to my future projects.
response.content_html: Thank you for your honest and full review Sara. I will definitely take these points and apply them to my future projects.

results.content:
This course felt well-paced and detailed. It went above and beyond just the .Net Core tutorial, but also how to DEPLOY the application. Since I am already an experienced developer, I didn't expect to learn THAT much more... but I did! Not only the deployment, but also a touch of CI/CD and a bit about important design patterns (Repository, UnitOfWork). This end-to-end tutorial approach is great.

Also, the course creator responded to questions and stayed engaged with me throughout the course.

I highly recommend this course for mid-to-senior developers, who want to get up to speed with the latest .Net Core / .Net 5.

response.content: I appreciate the thorough review Chinedu. I am glad that this course could have provided value to you.
response.content_html: I appreciate the thorough review Chinedu. I am glad that this course could have provided value to you.

results.content:
Went a lot deeper into underlying concepts than I initially expected, but not in a bad way. Everything was explained very well and is a well thought out course.
 I have been studying java and the spring framework for job opportunities, and was pleasantly surprised on how far developing with Microsoft has come as far as easy to read and logical code. I took this course to give me a foundation in .net development for a job posting near me and now I actually would prefer .net over spring if I had my choice. I enjoyed this course.

results.content:
The course is good at what it does and Trevoir has a good style that I find easy to follow and a clear voice. In reality the course is a good foundation for MVC even though that isn’t the title. 

If you want a foundation course on MVC then this is a great course. It is a little slow to start and becomes a bit repetitive because the example application isn’t a trivial one and includes several views that essentially perform similar operations (albeit on different data or to produce different views of it).

One thing I found frustrating is that in a few places very basic aspects of C# are explained (ie what the ! does in if(!x)) but pertinent details aren’t. An example being that the modelstate is glossed over without explaining it but googling it I found a good Microsoft explanation of what it is, how its produced, what it contains and what it does. Once I understood that it makes far more sense and is easily understandable. A simple slide is provided to explain scoped vs singleton vs transient but it just repeats the standard simple Microsoft explanation and isn’t helpful at explaining these which are important issues and deserved a full explanation. Similarly I felt that async was glossed over but is an extremely important topic.

Identity is covered and Trevoir explains extending the base Identity to include additional fields. It’s a very useful section and as with everything else covered if explained in a clear step-by-step manner. However, I really really wished it had gone further. My frustration is the course covers the basics but in many places falls into the common trap of just saying “you need to put this line of code here” without explaining the details or what’s actually happening within the framework. I think a weakness of the course is that it doesn’t explain the security issues and just glosses over things like ValidateAntiForgeryToken. At a couple of points Trevoir uses a js onclick function but warns that it creates a security issue and therefore isn’t good practice. I think at one point he says he’s going to explain this but unless I missed the explanation never does so. It would have been very useful to have a section on security.

The course is billed as the “complete” source on EF development. However, I was left wanting/needing more. It covers the essentials for an app with a small database with reasonably simple queries. However, there is no explanation that .net can execute some queries in the database whereas as soon as you cast the results to other data classes any query will be executed in memory having fetched all of the underlying records from the database. If you have a table with millions of records that quickly because extremely bad. Also the course doesn’t deal with only fetching limited columns to optimise performance and doesn’t deal with complex queries. The course assumes the use of automapper but does not really deal with building apps without automapper.

The course is billed as the complete course for EF and whilst it is a good course in the essentials of MVC I found it very lacking in terms of covering EF except in terms of the basics for a reasonably simple MVC app.

The course doesn’t cover Razor @pages (just razor views – its an MVC course) and doesn’t cover partial pages (except briefly mentioning the login view) or Razor components. I haven’t found a course that deals with partial pages, components, etc and disappointed that these aren’t covered. 

If you want a course focused on MVC and covering the essentials then this IS a good course and Trevoir is a good tutor.

response.content:
Paul, I sincerely appreciate your views on what is there and what is lacking. I have taken the feedback and will seek to stop these gaps as much as possible.

Thank you again for sharing your views.
response.content_html:
Paul, I sincerely appreciate your views on what is there and what is lacking. I have taken the feedback and will seek to stop these gaps as much as possible.

Thank you again for sharing your views.

results.content:
One of the best courses I've ever paid for - covers exactly what it claims to cover and more.  My expectations have been exceeded on every level.  

Instructor is fantastic - he explains everything that is happening and, unlike other courses I've taken, he explains WHY things are the way they are.  I'm sure we've all had the sad experience of taking courses that were presented as "monkey see, monkey do" and merely transmit information without understanding.  

By contrast, this instructor is the kind we all hope for.  He knows how to convey information WITH understanding to others.   Sadly, most so-called teachers are little more than reciters of trivia. 

I assume that, like me, you're smart enough to read documentation and obtain facts for yourself.  You probably don't have a hard time answering the question "How?"...but, what people like us need most is someone to answer the question "Why?" and to show how things fit into larger contexts, both in theory and in practice.  I don't know about you, but I'm fed up with creating "demonstration projects" that don't resemble their real-life counterparts.  I want to see how things are built in the real-world.  

This instructor and this course are absolutely great!! If they tripled the price tomorrow, I would pay it without hesitating, because this has been a freaking great value for my money.  I only wish this guy would put out more instructional courses, because he now has me as a devoted customer.  

BUY THIS COURSE!

response.content: I sincerely appreciate you taking the time out to leave this review Noah. I am glad that my explanations were well received and made a difference to you.

results.content:
I'm enjoying this course a lot. Midway through the course, I can already see how I can take the concepts learnt here and apply it in my own applications
As I finished the course, I realized how well Trevoir explained different concepts and I will definitely be able to take the lessons learned here and build my own applications.
For me, the difference between a good course and an amazing one would be to start the module with what we are going to do (how does what we are going to do next tie into the overall course), and end it with a review of steps (written somewhere). This is done in some places later on, but would advise to apply it earlier as well

results.content:
The "leave allocation module" was very confusing and unstructured (up to this point everything had a flow). The change of IdentityUser to Employee was pretty straightforward, but there is too much hopscotching around. Errors generated with the build and debugging were not explained at a level I could follow. Changing the ID property value from an int to a string stuck out as weird. 

Overall, this is the best course I have taken. Trevoir makes a great effort at using real world situations and applying a solution design to them. This is quality stuff - albeit, a lot of stuff to digest in one course. I am definitely more comfortable at the mid-point of this course than any other course.

Great job Trevoir.

response.content: Thank you for the feedback Jerry. I appreciate you taking the time to point out the pain points also. This helps me to understand the potential struggles students may have.
response.content_html: Thank you for the feedback Jerry. I appreciate you taking the time to point out the pain points also. This helps me to understand the potential struggles students may have.

results.content:
Useful tricks here and there. 
You must have a little patience to get through.

The good:
- Learned some MVC basics
- Learned about Identity and how to extend it. Very interesting.
- The LTE Admin implementation, the azure publish and iis impl were pretty nice.

Improvement areas:
- In most videos the code through the IDE can barely be seen, hope you can zoom it in.
- The project structure could be shown in a more explained way: the leave allocation part could be better in order to be more understandable, i mean, some friendly messages for letting know about the assignation of days. Maybe a little more depth explanation like a user story, as detailed as the database diagram shown at the beginning.

Keep up the good work, best regards.

response.content: Hello Mario, I sincerely appreciate your thorough review. I have made note of the improvement areas accordingly.
response.content_html: Hello Mario, I sincerely appreciate your thorough review. I have made note of the improvement areas accordingly.
